docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: IN 1965, when Congress was drafting legislation to create Medicare, the president of the American Medical Association testified against it, warning that there was ''no totally effective method'' to control its cost. Events bore out his warning: Despite many ingenious efforts to restrain the cost of the program, Medicare outlays continue to surge upward, raising serious questions about how the nation will pay for the health care that its elderly citizens want and need in the future.

headline.main: Medicare Expansion Imperiled by High Costs

headline.main: Pope Takes Hollywood But Not to Rave Review

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The Reagan Administration has told Congress that it is proposing to increase the premiums paid by Medicare beneficiaries by 38.5 percent next year, mainly because the cost of physicians' services for the elderly is rising much faster than had been expected.

headline.main: 38.5% RISE ASKED IN 1988 PREMIUMS OF MEDICARE USERS
